"A FEW WORDS ON BOOK BINDING\
\
Civilization is the set of tools by which man organizes and structures his life. The preservation and transmission of accumulated knowledge is the first of those tools; and, as a book without bindings will lose its organization and become torn and destroyed, so civilization itself depends on the bonds created by the book binders. Beyond the mere mechanical organization and durable protection which binding affords, of course, there are aesthetic values to books which only binders may produce. Over twenty binding materials are available to bookbinders within the Castle, from pasteboard to dragonscale."

"ON OPTIONS\
\
After a volume is bound, the color of the binding may be altered by a Dyer, and optionally adorned with a symbol or image by an Embosser. Bookbinders are encouraged to acquire skill in either or both of these crafts."

"MEASURES OF PROFICIENCY\
\
Ten levels of proficiency are recognized for the bookbinder's skill:\
\
1. Novice\
2. Junior Apprentice\
3. Senior Apprentice\
4. Fellowcraft\
5. Journeyman\
6. Artisan\
7. Senior Artisan\
8. Master\
9. Master Adept\
10. Grand Master\
\
A Novice bookbinder possesses very limited ability, and is able to attempt only a few rudimentary bindings. As skill increases, however, many more possibilities become available. A seasoned Master may command nearly two dozen binding options.\
\
The remainder of this hand-book describes the binding options available to bookbinders at each level of proficiency."

"NOVICE\
\
Novices are the least experienced bookbinders. Their binding options are admittedly rather drab and utilitarian.\
\
They only employ bindings of: none, paper, pasteboard, or ratskin."

"JUNIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Junior Apprentices know a bit more than Novices, but their additional skill can hardly be characterized as impressive.\
\
They will have learned the use of glassine, horsehide, and tinplate for bindings."

"SENIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Senior Apprentices have attained sufficient skill to employ a handful of modest but attractive binding options.\
\
These basic bindings include: cloth, pigskin, and copperplate."

"FELLOWCRAFT\
\
Fellowcraft bookbinders have spent many hours learning their trade, thereby earning the right to apply a personal mark of excellence onto the books bound by their skill.\
\
The materials of: leather and ironplate are often used by the Fellowcraft binders."

"JOURNEYMAN\
\
Journeymen possess the confidence to work with binding techniques of significant appeal.\
\
Their bindings now include vellum and nickelplate."

"ARTISAN\
\
Artisans have proven themselves capable of the fine control needed to produce some of the more challenging and beautiful bindings.\
\
In addition to the bindings which lesser bookbinders produce, they have acquired the skills to use goatskin or brassplate on their volumes."

"SENIOR ARTISAN\
\
Senior Artisans are sought by those desiring rare and exotic bindings for their treasured volumes. They often serve as assistants to Master bookbinders.\
\
They produce texts bound in calfskin or bronzeplate, in addition to all the lesser materials employed by lesser binders."

"MASTER\
\
Masters are the virtuosi of the bookbinder's art. Their long career of study and craftsmanship has earned them the ability to work with bindings requiring great skill. They can also alter the Binding of items that have already been altered.\
\
The remarkable materials of pheasantskin and silverplate can be employed by a Master."

"MASTER ADEPT\
\
Master Adepts have spent countless seasons honing their skills; theirs is often the highest skill present within the Castle.\
\
The luxurious binding materials of chamois and goldplate are sometimes employed by the Master Adepts."

"GRAND MASTER\
\
Grand Masters of the art of bookbinding appear infrequently within the Castle. The most important books of the Royal Library are bound by these rare individuals.\
\
If you should see a tome bound in either dragonscale or skyplate, you will realize that a Grand Master has utilized his or her exceptional skills on a no doubt important text."

"ON PROPRIETY AND DECENCY\
\
Bookbinders are expected to abide by Her Majesty's Capitulary regarding obscenity and inappropriate subjects. Any book offered for binding found to contain matter either treasonous, derogatory towards Her Majesty, corrupt, stolen, forged or otherwide criminal should be reported to Her Majesty's ministers.\
\
Bookbinders may also wish to consider their obligations in assisting any person publish a text containing insults, libel or provocative matter, or material regarded as confidential by persons other that the one offering the book for binding."

"UPDATES\
\
New binding techniques and materials are discovered from time to time; the text of this hand-book will mysteriously update itself as new choices become available. More skilled bookbinders will advise you when such changes occure.\
\
Please bring typographical errors or other textual problems found in this volume to the attention of the staff."
